definition: The point in a planet's orbit where it is farthest from the Sun. Earth reaches aphelion around July 4th each year.
visualExample: Imagine Earth's orbit as an oval. Aphelion is the point at the far end of the oval, away from the Sun.

definition: The point in a planet's orbit where it is closest to the Sun. Earth reaches perihelion around January 3rd each year.
visualExample: Using the oval orbit analogy, perihelion is the point at the near end, closest to the Sun.

definition: A small rocky object that orbits the Sun, typically found in the asteroid belt between Mars and Jupiter. Most asteroids are irregularly shaped.
visualExample: Think of asteroids as space rocks ranging from tiny pebbles to objects as large as mountains.

definition: A frozen ball of ice, dust, and rock that orbits the Sun. When close to the Sun, it develops a glowing tail due to evaporating ice.
visualExample: Picture a dirty snowball in space that grows a tail when it gets warm - that's a comet!

definition: A group of stars that appear to form a pattern in the sky. There are 88 official constellations recognized by astronomers.
visualExample: Like connect-the-dots in the night sky - Orion the Hunter and the Big Dipper are famous examples.

definition: When one celestial body moves into the shadow of another. Solar eclipses occur when the Moon blocks the Sun; lunar eclipses when Earth blocks sunlight from the Moon.
visualExample: Think of it as cosmic hide-and-seek - one object blocks the light from another.

definition: An orbit 35,786 km above Earth's equator where satellites move at the same speed as Earth's rotation, appearing stationary from the ground.
visualExample: Like a bird hovering in one spot while the ground rotates beneath it - perfect for weather and communication satellites.

definition: A large spacecraft orbiting Earth where astronauts live and conduct scientific experiments. It orbits at about 400 km altitude.
visualExample: A football-field-sized laboratory orbiting Earth every 90 minutes at 28,000 km/h.

definition: The distance light travels in one year - about 9.46 trillion kilometers. It's a unit used to measure distances between stars.
visualExample: If you could drive at highway speed, it would take about 10 million years to travel one light year!

definition: A streak of light in the sky caused by a small piece of space debris burning up in Earth's atmosphere. Also called a shooting star.
visualExample: The bright streaks you see during meteor showers - they're not stars falling, but tiny rocks burning up.

definition: A piece of rock or metal from space that survives passing through Earth's atmosphere and lands on the surface.
visualExample: A meteor that made it all the way to the ground without burning up completely.

definition: A giant cloud of dust and gas in space. Some nebulae are where new stars are born; others are created when old stars die.
visualExample: Cosmic clouds that can be nurseries for baby stars or the beautiful remains of dying stars.

definition: The curved path an object takes as it moves around another object due to gravity. Planets orbit the Sun; moons orbit planets.
visualExample: Like a ball on a string being swung in a circle - gravity is the invisible string keeping objects in orbit.

definition: The cargo carried by a spacecraft or rocket, such as satellites, scientific instruments, or supplies for astronauts.
visualExample: Everything a rocket carries into space that isn't fuel or the rocket itself.

definition: When a planet appears to move backward in the sky relative to the stars. This is an optical illusion caused by Earth passing the planet in orbit.
visualExample: Like when you pass a slower car on the highway - it seems to move backward relative to you.

definition: Any object that orbits another object. The Moon is a natural satellite of Earth; GPS satellites are artificial satellites.
visualExample: Anything in orbit around something else - from natural moons to human-made spacecraft.

definition: A sudden burst of energy from the Sun's surface, releasing intense radiation. Large flares can disrupt radio communications and power grids on Earth.
visualExample: Explosive bursts of energy from the Sun, like giant magnetic eruptions.

definition: A stream of charged particles constantly flowing outward from the Sun in all directions. It creates auroras when it interacts with Earth's magnetic field.
visualExample: An invisible river of particles flowing from the Sun - responsible for the Northern and Southern Lights.

definition: The explosive death of a massive star, briefly becoming as bright as an entire galaxy. It can create neutron stars or black holes.
visualExample: The most violent explosion in the universe - a dying star's last, brilliant moment.

definition: The path followed by an object moving through space, whether it's a satellite, rocket, or asteroid.
visualExample: The flight path of any object in space - like an arc a ball makes when you throw it.

definition: The point in the sky directly above an observer. When the Sun is at zenith, it casts no shadow.
visualExample: Look straight up - that's your zenith point.

definition: Colorful lights in the sky near Earth's poles, caused by solar wind particles colliding with gases in the atmosphere. Also called Northern or Southern Lights.
visualExample: Nature's light show - dancing curtains of green, red, and purple light in polar skies.

definition: A region in space with gravity so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape from it. Formed when massive stars collapse.
visualExample: Imagine a cosmic vacuum cleaner with infinite suction - nothing can escape once it gets too close.

definition: The two days each year when day and night are equal in length (about March 20 and September 22). Happens when the Sun crosses the celestial equator.
visualExample: The perfect balance point between seasons - equal daylight and darkness everywhere on Earth.

definition: A planet that orbits a star outside our solar system. Thousands have been discovered using telescopes.
visualExample: Planets orbiting other stars - potential homes for alien life we haven't found yet.

definition: A massive collection of stars, gas, and dust held together by gravity. Our galaxy, the Milky Way, contains over 100 billion stars.
visualExample: A cosmic city of stars - our Milky Way is just one of billions of galaxies in the universe.

definition: A measure of how bright a celestial object appears from Earth. Lower numbers are brighter; the Sun is -26.7, while the faintest stars visible are about +6.
visualExample: A brightness scale where smaller numbers mean brighter objects - like golf scores!

definition: National Aeronautics and Space Administration - the U.S. government agency responsible for space exploration and aeronautics research.
visualExample: America's space agency - the folks who put astronauts on the Moon and rovers on Mars.

definition: A unique identification number assigned to every satellite and piece of space debris tracked by the North American Aerospace Defense Command.
visualExample: Like a license plate for satellites - every object in orbit has its own tracking number.

definition: The time it takes for an object to complete one full orbit around another object. Earth's orbital period around the Sun is 365.25 days.
visualExample: How long it takes to go around once - like one lap on a race track.

definition: The point in a satellite's orbit where it is closest to Earth. Opposite of apogee.
visualExample: The low point of a satellite's orbit around Earth - where it swoops closest to our planet.

definition: The point in a satellite's orbit where it is farthest from Earth. Opposite of perigee.
visualExample: The high point of a satellite's orbit around Earth - where it's most distant from our planet.

definition: Zones of charged particles trapped by Earth's magnetic field. The Van Allen Belts are the most famous examples.
visualExample: Invisible donut-shaped zones around Earth filled with energetic particles - nature's radiation shields.

definition: The two days each year when the Sun reaches its highest or lowest point in the sky (around June 21 and December 21), marking the longest and shortest days.
visualExample: The turning points of the year - when we have the longest day (summer) or longest night (winter).

definition: A vehicle designed to travel in space, either with or without crew. Includes satellites, probes, space stations, and crewed capsules.
visualExample: Any vehicle built for space travel - from tiny CubeSats to massive space stations.

definition: Data transmitted from a spacecraft to ground stations, including information about the spacecraft's health, position, and scientific measurements.
visualExample: The vital signs and status reports that spacecraft send back to Earth - like text messages from space.

definition: When a celestial object passes directly between an observer and another object. Mercury and Venus can transit across the Sun's face.
visualExample: When a smaller object crosses in front of a larger one - like a tiny dot moving across the Sun.

definition: The darkest part of a shadow where all light is blocked. During a total solar eclipse, observers in the umbra see the Sun completely covered.
visualExample: The darkest core of a shadow - where you're completely in the dark.

definition: The lighter, outer part of a shadow where only some light is blocked. During a partial eclipse, observers in the penumbra see a partially covered Sun or Moon.
visualExample: The fuzzy edge of a shadow - where you're partially in the dark.

definition: The speed and direction of an object's motion. Orbital velocity is the speed needed to stay in orbit without falling.
visualExample: How fast and in what direction something is moving - like speed with a direction arrow.
